A 44-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department an hour after developing acute confusion. According to her husband, the patient had been experiencing headaches and blurry vision for the past several hours. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 205/110 mmHg. Physical examination shows right-sided weakness and loss of sensation. A CT scan of her head demonstrates an intraparenchymal hemorrhage. Despite appropriate treatment, the patient dies. A postmortem biopsy of her left adrenal gland is shown below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

This patient most likely also experienced which of the following symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with signs of hypertensive emergency (e.g., headache, blurry vision, altered mental status) and subsequently develops a hemorrhagic stroke, as demonstrated by her focal neurological deficits and head CT. Postmortem biopsy of the left adrenal gland reveals an intramedullary mass, which makes pheochromocytoma the likely underlying cause of her symptoms.

Pheochromocytomas are neuroendocrine tumors found in the adrenal medulla that secrete catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. On gross pathology, they appear as yellow-tan, well-defined lesions in the center of the adrenal gland.

The primary clinical manifestation of pheochromocytoma is hypertension. Many patients will have paroxysmal episodes caused by the sudden release of catecholamines. These episodic hypertensive episodes are associated with tachycardia, palpitations, headache, diaphoresis (sweating) and tremors. Some patients, like the one in this vignette, may develop life-threatening complications such as pulmonary edema, myocardial infarction, and strokes due to malignant hypertension.





Option Analysis

✅ Episodic diaphoresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Muscle weakness:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome (hypercortisolism) can result in muscle atrophy and weakness due to cortisol’s catabolic effects on protein metabolism. Likewise, hyperaldosteronism can cause significant hypokalemia, which would also manifest with muscle weakness. While both of these conditions may cause hypertension, it would be unusual for either of them to present with the hypertensive emergency seen in this patient.
❌ Hirsutism and purple abdominal striae:
Incorrect: Hirsutism and purple abdominal striae can be due to hypercortisolism. Although excessive cortisol synthesis can cause hypertension, it would be unusual for the condition to cause markedly elevated blood pressures that would result in hypertensive emergency. Furthermore, this patient’s biopsy demonstrates an adrenal medullary mass, which is more concerning for an underlying pheochromocytoma.
❌ Hyperpigmentation of the skin:
Incorrect: Cushing disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary mass can result in hypertension and skin hyperpigmentation. This patient’s biopsy shows a medullary mass in the adrenal gland, which makes another underlying etiology more likely.
❌ Exophthalmos:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism, such as in the case of Graves disease, can result in hypertension. Graves disease can also cause exophthalmos due to activation of retro-orbital fibroblasts. This patient’s biopsy shows a medullary mass in the adrenal gland, which makes another underlying etiology more likely.

questions.text: A 15-month-old boy is brought to the clinic after his parents noticed frequent falls and abnormal twitching of his limbs over the past month. Prior to the onset of these symptoms, the patient had been walking without assistance and developing normally. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows bilateral jerking eye movements and sporadic muscle contractions of the trunk and limbs. The patient has difficulty walking in a straight line and stumbles several times. A left-sided abdominal mass is palpated. Biopsy of the mass reveals small, round, blue cells arranged concentrically around a central neuropil. Staining with neuron-specific enolase is positive. Based on these findings, which of the following is most likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
This young boy who is presenting with an abdominal mass, opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome, and suggestive biopsy results likely has a neuroblastoma. This condition is associated with elevated vanillylmandelic acid levels.

Biopsy of a neuroblastoma will typically show small, primitive-appearing, blue cells with dark nuclei. Some of these small, round, blue cells are concentrically arranged around a central space filled with neuropil, forming Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemical stains for biologic markers such as neuron-specific enolase, bombesin, and neurofilament can be used to aid in the histologic diagnosis of neuroblastoma.

Due to their neural crest origin, neuroblastomas express the enzymes necessary for catecholamine synthesis. Subsequent degradation of these catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) leads to the formation of end products (e.g., vanillylmandelic acid, homovanillic acid). Detection of elevated urine levels of vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) can support the diagnosis of neuroblastoma.



Option Analysis

✅ Urinary vanillylmandelic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Aldosterone to renin ratio:
Incorrect: Patients with an aldosteronoma will have increased aldosterone levels but reduced renin levels, resulting in an increased aldosterone to renin ratio. An aldosteronoma can manifest with hypertension, hypokalemia, muscle aches, and weakness. However, an aldosteronoma would not manifest with the opsoclonus, myoclonus, and ataxia seen in this patient.
❌ 24-hour urine cortisol:
Incorrect: Elevated 24-hour urine cortisol can be seen in patients with Cushing syndrome or Cushing disease. Patients typically present with Cushingoid features (e.g., thin bruisable skin, stretch marks, muscle atrophy) as well as hypertension. This patient’s biopsy result and other clinical signs suggest a different etiology.
❌ Urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid:
Incorrect: Elevated 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) can be seen in carcinoid syndrome, which typically presents with diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, and wheezing. This patient’s biopsy results and other clinical signs suggest a different etiology.
❌ Plasma phenylalanine:
Incorrect: Elevated plasma phenylalanine can be seen in patients with phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (phenylketonuria). The condition presents with damage to the central nervous system and intellectual disability. This patient’s normal development and presence of opsoclonus-myoclonus-ataxia syndrome suggest a different etiology.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider because of skin changes that began three-months ago. She has noticed increased bruising and the development of purple-red stretch marks on the abdomen. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she intermittently uses a budesonide inhaler. She smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. In the office, her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 142/85 mmHg. Physical exam confirms the presence of ecchymoses and abdominal striae. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  146 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.9 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  26 mmol/L 
 Fasting glucose  137 mg/dL 
 24-hour urine cortisol*  72 µg/day 
 Serum ACTH**  35 pg/mL 

*Normal range: 4-40 µg/day
**Normal range: 5-20 pg/mL

The serum cortisol levels are significantly reduced in response to a high-dose of dexamethasone. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiology for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Excess ACTH production by lung tumor

questions.solution:
The clinical and laboratory findings in this patient are consistent with Cushing disease secondary to ACTH overproduction by a pituitary adenoma. Such patients can develop muscle weakness, weight gain, skin thinning and bruising, and fat redistribution. In addition, patients can develop hyperglycemia secondary to reduced glucose tolerance.

The first step in the work-up is to measure free cortisol in a 24-hour urine sample. Alternative methods include blood or saliva tests and a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.

If any of the aforementioned tests yield abnormal results, the next step is to determine the exact cause of excess cortisol production. This evaluation involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. Low ACTH levels are seen in adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinomas, and exogenous glucocorticoid use. High ACTH levels are seen in patients with Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) and ectopic ACTH production.

In patients with high ACTH levels, the next step is to give a high-dose injection of dexamethasone. If there is no decline in ACTH/cortisol levels, it means there is an ectopic site of ACTH production. If ACTH/cortisol levels fall after the high-dose dexamethasone test, it means that an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma is the cause.

The patient in this vignette has elevated ACTH levels and reduced endogenous cortisol production after administration of high-dose dexamethasone, which is consistent with Cushing disease. Surgical resection is the first-line treatment option.



Option Analysis

❌ Glucocorticoid overproduction by adrenal tumor:
Incorrect: A cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma can cause hypercortisolism. The condition will result in low ACTH levels due to the negative feedback that cortisol has on the pituitary gland. In contrast, this patient’s laboratory findings show an elevated ACTH level.
✅ ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Excess ACTH production by lung tumor:
Incorrect: Malignancies such as small cell lung cancer can secrete ACTH which, in turn, can cause increased glucocorticoid production. Patients with this condition are not expected to respond to a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. In contrast, this patient has reduced cortisol production after being administered a high dose of dexamethasone.
❌ Exogenous glucocorticoid intake:
Incorrect: Exogenous glucocorticoid intake can present with symptoms of hypercortisolism. In such instances, the body decreases (not increases) ACTH production in an attempt to reduce endogenous cortisol production and normalize blood cortisol levels. Moreover, intermittent use of inhaled corticosteroids (as in this patient) is not significant enough to cause hypercortisolism.
❌ Overactive posterior pituitary tumor:
 Incorrect: The clinical and laboratory findings in this patient are consistent with hypercortisolism. ACTH overproduction by the anterior pituitary can cause hypercortisolism However, none of the hormones produced by the posterior pituitary (vasopressin and oxytocin) can account for the patient’s symptoms.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to his physician for evaluation of worsening headaches and dizziness. The headaches tend to occur during periods of stress and are usually associated with blurry vision and tremors. In the office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 154/96 mmHg. Physical examination reveals brownish macules spread over his body, as well as numerous cutaneous nodules. The lesions are shown in the below image:

 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Given the patient’s history and physical exam findings, he should be assessed for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypertension, intermittent headaches, and visual disturbances. In addition, physical examination reveals brownish macules (cafe-au-lait spots) and numerous pedunculated lesions (cutaneous neurofibromas). In combination, these findings are concerning for an underlying pheochromocytoma due to neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1).

Most pheochromocytomas arise sporadically. However, 10% are associated with inherited syndromes such as NF-1, which occurs due to an autosomal dominant mutation in the NF1 gene on chromosome 17. Other conditions associated with pheochromocytomas include von Hippel-Lindau disease, multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A, and MEN 2B.

Pheochromocytomas typically arise in the adrenal medulla and are composed of chromaffin cells. These cells synthesize and release catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine). As a result, patients with pheochromocytomas will have catecholamine overproduction and oversecretion. This increase in serum catecholamines can manifest as paroxysmal episodes of hypertension, tachycardia, palpitations, headache, diaphoresis, and tremors due to the sudden release of catecholamines. Some patients, such as the one in this vignette, can demonstrate a chronic sustained elevation in blood pressure.

The characteristics of pheochromocytomas can be remembered with the “rule of tens,” which states that 10% are malignant, bilateral, extra-adrenal (e.g. bladder), calcified, and manifest in kids. Furthermore, 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes such as NF-1.





Option Analysis

✅ Adrenal medulla neoplasm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bilateral vestibular schwannomas:
Incorrect: Bilateral vestibular schwannomas, also termed acoustic neuromas, are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells. Bilateral neuromas are characteristic of neurofibromatosis type 2. In contrast, this patient likely has neurofibromatosis type 1, which is not associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas.
❌ Parathyroid hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Parathyroid hyperplasia can be seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1 and type 2A. Patients typically present with signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia (e.g., constipation, kidney stones, polyuria). However, this patient has multiple neurofibromas over his back, which is more concerning for neurofibromatosis type 1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 is not associated with parathyroid hyperplasia.
❌ Pancreatic neoplasm:
Incorrect: Pancreatic neoplasms, such as insulinomas and gastrinomas, are strongly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1. Although an increased incidence of pancreatic endocrine tumors has also been linked with neurofibromatosis type 1, another condition is more likely in this patient, especially given his current symptoms.
❌ Pituitary neoplasm:
Incorrect: Pituitary tumors can be seen in multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 1. Although these masses can also present with headaches and changes in vision, the visual changes are typically described as loss of temporal visual fields. Additionally, this patient’s cutaneous lesions are more suggestive of a different underlying condition.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of “changing facial features” that began seven-months ago. The patient describes that her forehead and jaw appear bigger than before. In addition, she endorses deepening of her voice and “being sweaty.” Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mmHg. As part of the work-up process, serum insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels are measured. In addition, growth hormone (GH) levels are measured before and after the administration of glucose. Which of the following sets of findings will most likely be seen in this patient?

choices.text: IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load Normal  Normal  ↓
IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↓↑↑
IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↓↑ ↓
IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↑↑↑
IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↑↑ ↓

questions.solution:
This patient’s history of changing facial features, hyperhidrosis, and deepening voice raises concern for acromegaly, a disorder of excess GH that is usually a result of a functional pituitary adenoma secreting GH.

There are three steps in the diagnostic process. The first step is to measure IGF-1, a growth factor produced by the liver in response to stimulation by GH which stimulates growth of the long bones. Daily GH secretion is pulsatile, but it stimulates the liver to release a constant amount of IGF-1. As a result, there is less variability between IGF-1 measurements, making IGF-1 a better predictor of GH excess.

If high IGF-1 levels are detected, the second step is to perform an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT), where serum GH is measured before and after glucose administration. In healthy individuals, elevated blood glucose will cause the body to stop producing GH. Inability to suppress GH secretion raises concern for a GH-secreting adenoma. The third step involves obtaining a brain MRI to assess the tumor’s location and size.

 


Treatment consists of transsphenoidal resection. If surgery is unsuccessful, dopamine agonists like cabergoline or GH receptor antagonists like pegvisomant can be used. Some cases might also require radiotherapy.

Option Analysis

❌ IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load Normal  Normal  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are expected in normal individuals. Oral glucose administration suppresses GH secretion and is the standard method for assessing inhibitory control of GH release. However, this patient’s history of changing facial features, hyperhidrosis, and voice deepening raise concerns for an underlying pathology of growth hormone excess.
❌  IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↓↑↑:
Incorrect: Although patients with acromegaly typically have elevated growth hormone levels that remain elevated after an oral glucose tolerance test, they also tend to have elevated IGF-1 levels.
❌ IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↓↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: This patient’s history of changing facial features, hyperhidrosis, and deepening voice all raise suspicion for acromegaly. However, patients with acromegaly will have elevated IGF-1 levels and elevated growth hormone levels that do not decrease after an oral glucose tolerance test.
✅  IGF-1  GH before oral glucose load  GH after oral glucose load ↑↑↑:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ IGF-1 GH before oral glucose load GH after oral glucose load ↑↑ ↓ :
Incorrect: Patients with acromegaly have elevated levels of growth hormone, which in turn increases IGF-1 production. However, the growth hormone levels will remain elevated even after administering an oral glucose tolerance test.

questions.text:
A 51-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider with complaints of fatigue and weakness. The symptoms began 6 months ago. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient is currently taking lisinopril and metformin. She consumes 4-6 beers per week. Her pulse is 86/min and blood pressure is 152/94 mmHg. BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals bilateral muscle weakness in the upper and lower extremities. Truncal obesity is present. Skin changes are observed on the patient’s back and the findings are shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons 

Similar changes are also noted on the patient’s abdomen. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s skin findings?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with muscle weakness, striae (as shown in the image), and weight gain. These are consistent with the presentation of Cushing syndrome, which describes the constellation of findings seen in patients with hypercortisolism.    

Excess cortisol leads to proteolysis. The muscle and skin, both of which are major sources of protein in the body, are broken down. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities. The skin becomes progressively thinner and can no longer conceal the color of venous blood in the underlying dermis, causing the purple-red striae to appear. Cortisol also stimulates gluconeogenesis, which results in hyperglycemia, and an increased appetite, which results in weight gain. This can manifest as truncal obesity. In addition, there is also fat redistribution to the cheeks, resulting in a round, moon-shaped face, and to the back of the neck, causing a suboccipital fat pad or “buffalo hump.” Cushing syndrome can also lead to hypertension. This is because cortisol can amplify the effect of catecholamines and act as a mineralocorticoid agonist.  

Patients with ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism may also present with hirsutism. This is because ACTH stimulates not only cortisol production in the zona fasciculata, but also androgen production in the zona reticularis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Excess melanin production:
Incorrect: Excess melanin production may be observed in patients with hypercortisolism secondary to a pituitary adenoma or ACTH-secreting malignancy. This is because ACTH and melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) are derived from the same precursor molecule; therefore increased ACTH production would also lead to increased MSH production. Excess melanin would result in hyperpigmentation as opposed to the purple-red striae shown in the image.  
✅ Skin atrophy and breakdown:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased adipose deposition:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette has hypercortisolism, which leads to increased appetite and body fat redistribution. This can lead to deposition of fat in the abdomen (truncal obesity), face (moon-faces), and behind the neck (buffalo hump). However, adipose deposition would not account for the striae observed in this patient.  
❌ Paraumbilical vein dilatation:
Incorrect: Dilation of the paraumbilical veins is often observed in patients with liver cirrhosis. Cirrhosis leads to portal hypertension, the formation of anastomoses, and ultimately engorgement of the paraumbilical veins. However, the dilated paraumbilical veins would appear swollen and blue-black in color and would not extend to the patient’s back.   
❌ Muscle atrophy and breakdown:
Incorrect: Hypercortisolism can lead to severe muscle breakdown. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities. However, the finding shown in the image is not due to muscle breakdown but is instead due to skin breakdown.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider with a concern of skin changes that began 4 months ago. The patient has no past medical history. The patient works as an attorney and spends most of his time indoors. During the visit, his temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F) and blood pressure is 141/84 mmHg. His BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable for a bulge beneath his occiput and purple striae located predominantly in the lower abdomen. The patient is also observed to have hyperpigmentation of the skin. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Cushing syndrome is the constellation of findings seen in patients with hypercortisolism. Excess cortisol leads to muscle and skin breakdown. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities, easy bruising and abdominal striae (reddish-purple streaks). The bones are also broken down for calcium resorption, so fractures can occur due to osteoporosis. Cortisol also stimulates gluconeogenesis, which results in hyperglycemia, and increased appetite, which results in weight gain. This can manifest as truncal obesity (accumulation of adipose at the abdomen). However, there is also fat redistribution to the cheeks, resulting in a round, moon-shaped face, and to the back of the neck leading to the development of a suboccipital fat pad, or “buffalo hump.” Cushing syndrome can also lead to hypertension since cortisol amplifies the effect of catecholamines and acts as a mineralocorticoid agonist.  

Cushing syndrome can be due to high levels of exogenous or endogenous cortisol. The most common cause of Cushing syndrome is chronic corticosteroid use. Endogenous causes include adrenal tumors, malignancies that secrete ectopic ACTH, and overproduction of ACTH by a pituitary adenoma. The latter is termed Cushing disease.  

Patients with Cushing disease will have elevated ACTH levels and skin hyperpigmentation. This is because melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) is cleaved from the same precursor as ACTH; therefore, increased production of ACTH would also lead to an increased production of MSH. In contrast, patients with hypercortisolism due to exogenous corticosteroid use or an adrenal tumor would have low ACTH levels and no skin pigmentation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Overactive posterior pituitary adenoma:
Incorrect: The posterior pituitary secretes vasopressin and oxytocin. An overactive posterior pituitary adenoma can result in the excess production of either of these hormones. However, neither excess oxytocin or vasopressin production would account for the striae and sub-occipital bulge (termed a “buffalo’s hump”) noted in this patient.  
✅ Overactive anterior pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperfunctioning renin-secreting tumor  :
Incorrect: Overproduction of renin can lead to increased downstream aldosterone production and cause hypertension. However, a renin-secreting tumor would not account for the skin findings observed in this patient. Instead, the abdominal striae and suboccipital hump are most consistent with the presentation of hypercortisolism.  
❌ Hyperfunctioning cortisol-secreting tumor:
Incorrect: A cortisol-secreting tumor can account for many of the patient’s findings. However, the patient’s skin hyperpigmentation is most likely due to ACTH overproduction. This is because melanocyte stimulating hormone (MSH) is cleaved from the same precursor as ACTH. So increased ACTH production would also lead to increased MSH production. In contrast, patients with hypercortisolism due to a cortisol-secreting tumor would have low ACTH levels and no skin pigmentation.  
❌ Hyperfunctioning aldosterone-secreting tumor:
Incorrect: An aldosterone-secreting tumor can cause hypertension. However, an aldosterone-secreting tumor would not account for the patient’s weight gain, skin findings, and suboccipital hump.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his physician due to progressive weight gain over the past 6 months. The patient has moderate, persistent bronchial asthma, which is well-controlled with as-needed inhaled corticosteroids and albuterol. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 161/96 mmHg. There are scattered ecchymoses on the extremities and mild proximal muscle weakness is present. Laboratory testing and imaging is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Abdominal CT reveals an adrenal tumor on the right side, with mild atrophy of the left adrenal gland. This patient most likely has which of the following laboratory patterns of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis activity?
questions.solution:
This patient has weight gain, muscle weakness, skin ecchymosis, and hypertension. CT imaging reveals a right-sided adrenal mass. These findings are consistent with Cushing syndrome secondary to a cortisol-producing adrenal tumor, which would manifest with elevated serum cortisol levels. The high cortisol levels suppress hypothalamic corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) production and anterior pituitary adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production.

The first step in the work-up of hypercortisolism is to measure free cortisol in a 24-hour urine sample. Alternatively, blood or saliva tests at midnight can help check if there is a normal daily rise and fall of cortisol levels. Another option is the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. During the test, the individual is given a low dose of dexamethasone, an exogenous steroid that suppresses pituitary ACTH production. In healthy individuals, this would cause a decrease in serum cortisol levels.

If any of the aforementioned tests yield abnormal results, the next step is to determine the exact cause of excess cortisol production. This involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. Low ACTH levels are seen in adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinomas, and exogenous glucocorticoid use. In contrast, high ACTH levels are seen in patients with Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) and ectopic ACTH production. Finally, if an adrenal tumor is suspected, then abdominal CT or MRI can confirm the tumor’s location and differentiate benign from malignant tumors.

 



Option Analysis

✅   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↓  ↓  ↑ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↓  ↓ ↓:
Incorrect: These laboratory findings can be seen in patients with adrenal insufficiency due to suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis. Patients with adrenal insufficiency typically present with hypotension, as opposed to hypertension. 
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↓  ↑ ↑:
Incorrect: Elevated ACTH and cortisol with decreased CRH levels are concerning for secondary hypercortisolism due to an ACTH-secreting anterior pituitary adenoma. However, this diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who has a right adrenal tumor and atrophied left adrenal gland, which is more concerning for primary hypercortisolism.
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↑↑ ↓:
Incorrect: Increased levels of CRH and ACTH with decreased cortisol suggest primary adrenal insufficiency. In contrast, this patient has hypertension, increased bruising, and muscle weakness, which are more consistent with the symptoms of hypercortisolism.
❌   Corticotropin-Releasing Hormone (CRH)  Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)  Cortisol  ↑  ↓  ↑ :
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of hypercortisolism in the setting of a right adrenal mass, which is concerning for a cortisol-secreting adrenal tumor. Patients with this condition would have elevated serum cortisol, decreased ACTH, and decreased CRH levels.

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the function of a gene in a patient population that is predisposed to developing malignant tumors. Study of one particular female patient revealed the development of breast cancer and adrenocortical carcinoma before the age of 45. Her father passed away from a bone sarcoma at the age of 43, and her brother died at an early age after developing leukemia. Molecular analysis of the protein product of the wild-type gene reveals that it activates phosphoprotein 21, which subsequently inhibits progression of the cell cycle. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient and her family likely have a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene TP53, which encodes the p53 protein. When DNA damage is detected, normal-functioning p53 activates phosphoprotein 21 (p21), which inhibits the function of cyclins. Since cyclins act to progress the cell cycle, p53 therefore is involved in blocking the G1 to S phase transition when DNA damage is detected. However, when p53 is mutated, the checkpoint between the G1 and S phase is lost, and uncontrolled cell proliferation occurs.

Li-Fraumeni syndrome is an inherited autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations of the TP53 gene. The condition leads to a wide range of malignancies that appear at an unusually early age. Li-Fraumeni syndrome is also known as the Sarcoma, Breast, Leukemia, and Adrenal Gland (SBLA) cancer syndrome, due to the cancers it can cause.



Option Analysis

✅ TP53:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ RB1:
Incorrect: Retinoblastoma protein, encoded by the RB1 gene, is a tumor suppressor protein that also inhibits progression of the cell cycle from G1 to S phase. This protein, however, binds instead to E2F transcription factors. Furthermore, a mutation in the RB1 gene is more strongly associated with malignancies such as retinoblastoma.
❌ BRCA1:
Incorrect: The BRCA1 gene encodes a protein that is heavily involved in DNA repair. Mutations in this gene are associated with an increased risk of breast cancer, as well as ovarian and colon cancers. This patient’s family history of adrenocortical tumors, leukemia, and sarcoma are suggestive of another gene mutation.
❌ VHL:
Incorrect: The VHL gene encodes a tumor suppressor protein that normally inhibits hypoxia-inducible factor 1a. A mutation in this gene can result in von Hippel-Lindau disease, which would present with hemangioblastoma in the retina and cerebellum, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytomas.
❌ KRAS:
Incorrect: The KRAS gene, when mutated, produces an oncogenic protein that results in overproliferation of cells. It can be the cause of colorectal, lung, or pancreatic cancers. KRAS is not involved in activating phosphoprotein 21 or inhibition of the cell cycle.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents for worsening headaches that have interfered with his ability to concentrate at school. The patient describes the pain as dull and continuous. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Visual testing reveals reduced peripheral vision in both eyes. A head CT is ordered, and the results are as follows:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The mass is surgically resected. Subsequent histology reveals calcifications as well as cysts filled with brownish, cholesterol-rich fluid. The mass is most likely a derivative of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
This patient has a craniopharyngioma. The tumor originates from the residual anterior pituitary embryonic tissue, called the Rathke pouch. Symptoms depend on the tumor’s location. If it involves the area of the pituitary gland itself, the tumor can cause partial or complete pituitary hormone deficiency, leading to hypopituitarism. If the tumor compresses the pituitary stalk, it can impair antidiuretic hormone secretion from the posterior pituitary, leading to diabetes insipidus. A large craniopharyngioma can increase prolactin levels by interfering with hypothalamic dopamine release, ultimately causing galactorrhea, and can also result in compression symptoms like headaches and bitemporal hemianopia.

Diagnosis is based on a brain imaging (e.g. MRI), which shows calcifications (hyperdense) and fluid-filled cysts (hypodense). Histology of the mass will reveal a solid component, which are the tumor cells, a cystic component filled with cholesterol-rich fluid, and a calcified component. Treatment involves surgical resection of the mass.



Option Analysis

❌ Posterior pituitary gland:
Incorrect: The patient’s imaging and histological findings are concerning for a craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngiomas are derived from surface ectoderm. In contrast, the posterior pituitary gland is derived from neuroectoderm.
❌ Astrocytes:
Incorrect: Pilocytic astrocytomas are the most common pediatric brain tumor. The condition most often arises in the cerebellum and causes symptoms related to elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., headaches, nausea, vomiting). However, histological analysis will reveal Rosenthal fibers (eosinophilic corkscrew fibers) rather than cholesterol-rich fluids.
✅ Remnants of the Rathke pouch:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pia mater:
Incorrect: The Pia mater is the innermost layer of the meninges. It can give rise to meningiomas. These tumors are most often found near the brain’s surface, and histology will reveal Psammoma bodies. In contrast, this patient’s mass is located at the base of the brain, with histological findings of cholesterol-rich fluid.
❌ Pineal gland:
Incorrect: A pinealoma is a pediatric brain tumor that usually presents with vertical gaze palsy and obstructive hydrocephalus. The pineal gland is located in the dorsal midbrain. In contrast, this patient’s mass is in the suprasellar region.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office because of weakness and amenorrhea over the past two months. Her only medications are albuterol and an inhaled glucocorticoid for asthma. Her current BMI is 28 kg/m2 (previously 23 kg/m2). Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/104 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a rounded face, increased fat deposition at the back of the neck, and purple lesions across the abdomen. Her 8 AM serum cortisol level is 42 μg/dL (reference range: 0800 cortisol <5 μg/dL) and her serum adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is 65 pg/mL (reference range: 0800 ACTH = 10 - 60 pg/mL). High-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of both cortisol and ACTH levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with amenorrhea and weakness, with a physical examination showing weight gain, hypertension, rounding of her face (“moon facies”), fat deposition on the back of the neck (“buffalo hump”), and abdominal striae, which are characteristic of Cushing syndrome. Other findings include hirsutism, osteoporosis, hyperglycemia (insulin resistance), immunosuppression, and skin thinning. Cushing syndrome refers to the collection of symptoms that result from hypercortisolism. The most common cause is exogenous glucocorticoid intake, leading to iatrogenic Cushing syndrome. The most common endogenous cause of Cushing syndrome is an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor (as in this patient), which is called Cushing disease.  

Initial screening tests for Cushing syndrome can be done by first demonstrating hypercortisolism, either from an elevated late night salivary cortisol or elevated free cortisol on 24-hour urinalysis. A confirmatory screening step is an overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test, which, in Cushing syndrome, would demonstrate a cortisol level that is not suppressed. After high levels of cortisol has been confirmed, the next best step is to measure the ACTH levels, which determines whether the elevated cortisol is ACTH dependent or ACTH independent. If the ACTH levels are low, this is ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome, which could be either iatrogenic or caused by an adrenal mass.  

If the ACTH is high, this is ACTH-dependant Cushing syndrome. In this case, a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test can determine whether the ACTH is coming from the pituitary gland or from an ectopic source (e.g. small cell lung cancer). The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test will suppress ACTH and cortisol in the case of a pituitary adenoma (Cushing disease), but not in the case of ectopic ACTH secretion.    



Option Analysis

❌ Iatrogenic Cushing syndrome:
Incorrect: Exogenous corticosteroid intake (e.g. for autoimmune diseases) is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome. This patient is using inhaled, not systemic, corticosteroids, making this an unlikely cause. In addition, her ACTH levels were high at baseline, which excludes exogenous causes.   
✅ Cushing disease  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Adrenal adenoma:
Incorrect: An adrenal adenoma can cause Cushing syndrome by increasing endogenous glucocorticoid production. However, this would present with high levels of cortisol and low levels of ACTH at baseline. This patient’s laboratory findings, namely the high ACTH and high cortisol levels that were suppressed following a high-dose suppression test, favor the diagnosis of Cushing disease.   
❌ Small-cell lung carcinoma  :
Incorrect:  Small-cell lung cancer is a neuroendocrine tumor that can secrete ectopic ACTH and cause Cushing syndrome. The ectopic ACTH secretion from the tumor presents with high ACTH and high cortisol levels at baseline. However, no changes are expected even after a high-dose suppression test, as the tumor does not react to the negative feedback.   
❌ Adrenal carcinoma:
Incorrect: An adrenal carcinoma, similar to an adrenal adenoma, can cause Cushing syndrome by increasing glucocorticoid production. However, this would present with high levels of cortisol and low levels of ACTH at baseline, because the elevated cortisol levels lead to negative feedback on the pituitary gland. This patient has high ACTH and high cortisol levels that are suppressed following a high-dose suppression test, which favors the diagnosis of cushing disease.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man seeks evaluation for fatigue and “skin changes” that began 5 months ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and asthma. He is currently taking propranolol and uses a budesonide inhaler intermittently. The patient’s BMI is 35 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 152/83 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination shows scattered ecchymoses and purple abdominal striae. There is symmetric muscle weakness in the upper and lower extremities. The patient also has deposition of fat on the back of his neck. The patient’s ACTH level is measured at 4 pg/mL (normal range: 5-20 pg/mL). Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient’s findings?

choices.text: Overproduction of glucocorticoids by adrenal adenoma

questions.solution:
The patient has Cushing syndrome most likely due to a cortisol-secreting adrenal adenoma, a benign tumor of the adrenal gland. This is supported by the low ACTH levels on laboratory testing. Adrenal carcinomas, malignant tumors of the gland, are another less common cause of ACTH-independent hypercortisolism.    

The excess cortisol provides negative feedback. This means that high levels of cortisol inhibit hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH, respectively. This does not have any effect on zona fasciculata of the pathologic adrenal gland, since the neoplastic cells are autonomous and grow independently from ACTH. However, the zona fasciculata of the uninvolved, adrenal gland atrophies due to reduced ACTH stimulation. Hence, the discovery of asymmetrically sized adrenal glands on imaging (e.g. abdominal CT) could help narrow down the underlying cause of the patient’s hypercortisolism.    

Option Analysis

✅ Overproduction of glucocorticoids by adrenal adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Overactive anterior pituitary gland:
Incorrect: The anterior pituitary produces ACTH, which acts on the adrenal glands to promote glucocorticoid synthesis. While this patient has symptoms of hypercortisolism, the low ACTH measurement suggests that primary hypercortisolism (due to an adrenal gland pathology) is the most likely cause. In contrast, secondary hypercortisolism (due to a pituitary gland tumor) presents with elevated ACTH levels.  
❌ Glucocorticoid production by lung mass  :
Incorrect: Malignancies such as small cell lung cancer can secrete ACTH. This in turn causes increased glucocorticoid production. However, patients with this condition are expected to have an elevated serum ACTH.  
❌ Infarction of anterior pituitary gland:
Incorrect: This describes Sheehan syndrome, which results in reduced serum ACTH levels. Without ACTH secretion, patients would have reduced glucocorticoid production. This causes adrenal insufficiency and can present with lethargy, nausea/vomiting, and hypotension. Adrenal insufficiency would not present with the weight gain, muscle weakness, and suboccipital fat deposition that are noted in this patient.  
❌ Exogenous glucocorticoid intake:
Incorrect: Exogenous glucocorticoid intake can present with symptoms of hypercortisolism. The body in turn decreases ACTH production in an attempt to reduce endogenous cortisol production and normalize blood cortisol levels. The patient in this vignette is using a budesonide inhaler, but intermittent use of inhaled corticosteroids is not enough to cause hypercortisolism.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue and 5 kg (11 lb) weight gain over the past 4 months. In addition, the patient reports headaches that are worse in the morning. Past medical history is notable for asthma, and he is currently managed with albuterol and predisonoline inhalers. He is not taking any other medications. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F) and blood pressure is 147/80 mmHg. Physical exam is notable for 4/5 muscle strength in the upper and lower extremities. The patient also has wide reddish-purple streaks on the abdomen. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
 Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  146 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mmol/L 
 Fasting glucose  133 mg/dL 
 Serum ACTH*  35 pg/mL 
*Normal range: 5-20 pg/mL  
Which of the following findings would be most likely present in this patient’s adrenal glands?

choices.text: Hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata and reticularis
Atrophy of the zona fasciculata and reticularis

questions.solution:
The patient has Cushing disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, a benign tumor of the pituitary gland. This diagnosis is supported by the elevated ACTH levels on laboratory testing and the morning headaches, since the expanding mass causes elevated intracranial pressure, which is normally highest in the morning. Additional causes of ACTH overproduction include malignancies such as small-cell lung cancer and renal cell carcinoma, which can secrete ACTH as part of their paraneoplastic syndromes, causing Cushing syndrome.  

Regardless of the source, excess ACTH will stimulate the adrenal glands. In particular, ACTH will act on the zona fasciculata and reticularis to induce cortisol and androgen production, respectively. Over time, there will be hyperplasia of both the zona fasciculata and reticularis.   

Excess cortisol leads to severe muscle and skin breakdown. This leads to muscle wasting and thin extremities, easy bruising and abdominal striae (reddish-purple streaks). Patients can also develop fractures secondary to osteoporosis. Cortisol also stimulates gluconeogenesis, which results in hyperglycemia, and increased appetite, which results in weight gain, particularly to the abdomen. There is also fat redistribution to the cheeks, resulting in a round, moon-shaped face, and to the back of the neck, causing “buffalo hump.” Cushing syndrome can also lead to hypertension, since cortisol can act as a mineralocorticoid agonist and amplify the effects of catecholamines.  

Option Analysis

❌ Hyperplasia of the zona glomerulosa:
Incorrect: The zona glomerulosa produces aldosterone. It is regulated upstream by renin and angiotensin. Conditions such as a renin-secreting tumor or sarcoidosis, which increases angiotensin production, would cause hyperplasia of the zona glomerulosa and increased aldosterone production. This would explain the patient’s hypertension but would not account for the striae or muscle weakness.   
❌ Atrophy of the zona glomerulosa:
Incorrect: The zona glomerulosa is involved in aldosterone production, which regulates serum sodium and blood pressure. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms of abdominal striae, muscle atrophy, and hyperglycemia are most consistent with the presentation of hypercortisolism. The zona glomerulosa is not directly involved in cortisol synthesis. 
✅ Hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata and reticularis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atrophy of the zona fasciculata and reticularis:
Incorrect: The patient has elevated serum ACTH levels. This finding, in combination with the patient’s morning headaches, is suggestive of a pituitary adenoma. The adenoma will release excess ACTH, leading to increased corticosteroid production by the zona fasciculata and reticularis. Over time, these regions of the adrenal gland will undergo hyperplasia, as opposed to atrophy. 
❌ Hyperplasia of the adrenal medulla:
Incorrect: The adrenal medulla is involved in the production of catecholamines. Catecholamine overproduction may account for the patient’s hypertension and headaches, but it would not account for the muscle weakness and abdominal striae.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the office complaining of consistent diarrhea for the last 2 months. The patient has experienced watery, tea-colored diarrhea that happens even when she has not eaten anything. She denies any associated abdominal pain or difficulty swallowing. The patient feels fatigued and weak with muscle cramps which she attributes to being dehydrated. Medical history includes hyperparathyroidism and nephrolithiasis. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor without abdominal tenderness. Laboratory tests show the following:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Sodium  144 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.5 mEq/L 
 Chloride  93 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  21 mEq/L 
 Calcium   12 mg/dL 
 Glucose  250 mg/dL 
 Parathyroid hormone  350 pg/mL 

Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms are caused by the effects of excess vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) from a VIPoma. VIP is a neuropeptide that functions as a neuromodulator and neurotransmitter, and a VIPoma is a rare endocrine tumor that usually originates from the non-β islet cells of the pancreas. VIP’s effects include vasodilation, smooth muscle relaxation, and bicarbonate secretion from bile duct cholangiocytes. In excess, VIP binds to intestinal epithelial cells, increasing cAMP and causing fluid and electrolyte secretion into the lumen, which results in profuse secretory diarrhea with hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Electrolyte derangements and dehydration cause symptoms of fatigue, muscle cramps, flushing, and weakness.  .

VIPomas are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 1 (MEN type 1). MEN1 is a gene that is found on chromosome 11 and codes for a tumor suppressor protein called menin, which  normally stops cells from dividing uncontrollably. MEN1 mutations cause MEN type 1, which is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder. There are three types of tumors associated with MEN type 1: parathyroid, pancreatic, and pituitary. This patient has a history of hyperparathyroidism from a parathyroid adenoma, as well as symptoms consistent with a pancreatic tumor, the VIPoma, suggesting a diagnosis of MEN type 1.  


Other pancreatic tumors that can occur in MEN type 1 include gastrinomas (stomach ulcers) and insulinomas (hypoglycemia) or glucagonomas (hyperglycemia). Pituitary adenomas may include prolactinomas (galactorrhea, gynecomastia) and growth hormone-releasing tumors (gigantism, acromegaly). Although parathyroid tumors can also occur in MEN type 2, pancreatic and pituitary tumors are exclusively found in MEN type 1.  

Option Analysis

❌ Calcitonin secretion:
Incorrect: Calcitonin is a peptide hormone released by the parafollicular cells (C cells) of the thyroid gland. Its normal function is to reduce serum calcium levels, opposing the actions of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Calcitonin levels can be elevated from medullary thyroid cancer, which is seen in MEN type 2A and MEN type 2B, but it is unlikely to be seen in this patient with MEN type 1.   
❌ Catecholamine secretion:
Incorrect: Tumor secretion of the catecholamines norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine are responsible for the symptoms associated with a pheochromocytoma, including hypertension, headache, sweating, and tachycardia. Pheochromocytoma is almost never associated with MEN type 1, from which this patient likely suffers.
❌ Gastrin secretion:
Incorrect: Gastrin is a peptide hormone released by the G cells in the pyloric antrum of the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas that stimulates secretion of gastric acid by the parietal cells of the stomach. Gastrinomas, specifically of pancreatic origin, are associated with MEN type 1; however, they typically cause upper gastrointestinal ulcers and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), as opposed to this patient’s persistent diarrhea and electrolyte derangements.   
❌ Somatostatin secretion:
Incorrect: Somatostatin is a peptide hormone secreted by delta cells in the pyloric antrum of the stomach, duodenum, and pancreas that acts on G protein-coupled somatostatin receptors to inhibit the release of several secondary hormones, including insulin and glucagon. Somatostatin analogues are used in the treatment of several neuroendocrine tumors.  
✅ Vasoactive intestinal peptide secretion:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.

questions.text: A 14-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents due to constipation and poor feeding over the past week. According to the patient’s parents, she has not had a bowel movement in several days and has been eating and drinking significantly less than before. Prior to these symptoms, the patient had been developing normally. In the office, her temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 118/min, and blood pressure is 135/96 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals a palpable right-sided immobile abdominal mass that crosses the midline. Elevated levels of catecholamine byproducts are detected in the urine. A mutation in which of the following genes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This young girl presents with an abdominal mass that crosses the midline and elevated urinary catecholamine metabolites. She likely has a neuroblastoma.

Neuroblastomas are malignant tumors of the sympathetic nervous system. They are composed of poorly differentiated “neuroblasts,” which originate from the neural crest, and they can occur anywhere in the sympathetic chain and adrenal medulla. The condition is due to deletions of chromosome 1p that lead to amplification of the MYCN oncogene (also called N-myc). The MYCN gene codes for the DNA binding transcription factor N-myc. Its mutation leads to persistently high levels of N-myc, resulting in malignant transformation.

Similar to pheochromocytomas, neuroblastomas produce catecholamines, especially norepinephrine and dopamine. However, neuroblastomas do not typically cause severe hypertension because these tumors do not usually secrete the more potent epinephrine. Children with neuroblastoma of the adrenal medulla can have a large, painful abdominal mass that crosses the midline. In contrast, Wilms tumors do not typically cross the midline. The enlarging neuroblastoma can compress nearby structures and cause symptoms related to compression of the bowel or bladder (e.g., constipation, reduced bladder capacity, enuresis). Constitutional symptoms, such as fever, weight loss, and fatigue, can arise as the tumor releases inflammatory chemokines.





Option Analysis

✅ MYCN:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ KRAS:
Incorrect: KRAS protooncogene mutations can be responsible for the growth of various tumors, such as colorectal, lung, and pancreatic cancers. It is not, however, implicated in neuroblastomas.
❌ RB:
Incorrect: RB is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes the retinoblastoma protein. This protein is responsible for cell cycle arrest and is implicated in retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma. It is not, however, implicated in neuroblastomas.
❌ WT1:
Incorrect: WT1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a transcription factor that regulates urogenital development. Mutations in this gene are associated with the development of nephroblastomas (Wilms tumors), which can present as a unilateral abdominal mass. However, this patient’s abdominal mass crosses the midline, and the elevated urinary catecholamines are unlikely to be explained by a Wilms tumor.
❌ VHL:
Incorrect: VHL is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes a protein involved in the degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1a. Mutations in this gene can cause von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, which is associated with hemangioblastomas, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma. However, none of these aforementioned conditions would typically present as an abdominal mass that crosses the midline.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the office for the evaluation of bilateral nipple discharge. She first noticed it in her bra a few days ago. The patient does not have fever or breast pain. Menarche was at age 13. She has had a regular menstrual cycle until a year ago, when her menses slowed to 3-4 month intervals before stopping completely 6 months ago. She is sexually active with her male partner for 3 years and uses condoms consistently. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother at the age of 65. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows white discharge expressible from both nipples. Neurological examination reveals diminished vision in the temporal visual fields bilaterally. Urine Beta-HcG is negative. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
This woman’s presentation with bilateral white nipple discharge (galactorrhea) and oligomenorrhea, in combination with bitemporal hemianopia, is consistent with hyperprolactinemia most likely due to a prolactin secreting pituitary adenoma. She is at increased risk of infertility.

Prolactin is secreted by lactotrophs, a group of cells in the anterior pituitary gland. Prolactin levels are usually kept in check by the hypothalamus in two ways. Its release is under tonic inhibition by dopamine released from hypothalamic neurons. Release can be stimulated by thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH), also called prolactin releasing hormone, from the hypothalamus. Inhibition of dopamine release by certain medications (e.g. antipsychotics) or increase in the levels of TRH (e.g. in hypothyroidism) can result in hyperprolactinemia.

Furthermore, during pregnancy, elevated levels of estrogen stimulate the lactotrophs to produce large amounts of prolactin, which stimulates alveolar cells in the breasts, leading to physiologic hyperprolactinemia and lactation.

Clinical findings of hyperprolactinemia include oligo/amenorrhea, galactorrhea and, if severe, vaginal dryness and hot flashes. If unrecognized, it can result in hypogonadism, infertility and decreased bone density.



Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial carcinoma:
Incorrect: Endometrial carcinoma results from an excess of estrogen and a decreased progesterone level, as seen in polycystic ovarian syndrome. Hyperprolactinemia, on the other hand, inhibits the production and release of estrogen via negative feedback to the hypothalamus. It is unlikely to increase the risk of endometrial carcinoma. 
❌ Paget disease of breast:
Incorrect: A family history of breast cancer at the age of 60 does not increase the risk of developing Paget disease of breast, which is characterized by nipple ulceration and is associated with malignancy. Moreover, galactorrhea is not associated with breast cancer.
❌ Gonadal tumor:
Incorrect: Common risk factors for ovarian tumor include older age, early menarche and late menopause. Hyperprolactinemia does not increase the risk of a gonadal tumor.
❌ Virilization:
Incorrect: Virilization results from elevated testosterone levels, which can be caused by adrenal tumors. Hyperprolactinemia decreases estrogen levels, but it does not affect serum testosterone concentrations in women. Hence, it will not increase the risk of virilization in this patient.
✅ Infertility:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 15-year old boy is brought to a pediatrician by his parents for evaluation of abnormal growth. The patient is much taller than his classmates and is captain of the school’s basketball team. In the office, his height is measured to be 201 cm. His father’s height is 180 cm and his mother’s height is 167 cm. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits. Physical exam is notable for disproportionately long arms and legs, a protruding jaw, and reduced peripheral vision in both eyes. The remainder of the physical exam is noncontributory. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This young boy with a height of 201 cm, disproportionately long arms and legs and protruding jaw is exhibiting signs of gigantism, a condition that is caused by excessive growth hormone production. The physical examination finding of mass effect (e.g. bitemporal hemianopsia) points towards a pituitary adenoma as the most likely cause.

Clinically, growth hormone excess causes increased body size and height, with disproportionately long arms and legs. Since the growth plates have not fused, children with growth hormone excess can become very tall (sometimes exceeding 2 meters). Growth of the skull bones can result in coarsening of the facial features, prognathia, and frontal bossing. In gigantism, there can also be enlargement of visceral organs such as the heart. Lastly, if the pituitary adenoma becomes large enough to compress the optic chiasm, it can lead to impaired peripheral vision.

Of note, if an adult has a growth hormone secreting pituitary adenoma, then the condition is termed acromegaly. Since the growth plates have already fused, adults with growth hormone excess do not become taller. Instead, they will present with coarsening facial features, macrognathia, frontal bossing, as well as widened hands and feet.

 

Option Analysis

❌ Congenital defect in fibrillin protein:
Incorrect: A congenital defect in fibrillin protein typically leads to Marfan syndrome, which is characterized by tall stature and disproportionately long extremities. Patients also develop myopia due to lens dislocation. However, it would be atypical for Marfan syndrome to present with bitemporal hemianopsia.
❌ Familial predisposition to tall stature:
Incorrect: Both the patient’s mother and father are taller than average. However, patients with constitutional tall stature generally present with limbs that are proportional to the remainder of the body. Moreover, this explanation would not account for the patient’s macrognathia and visual field deficits.
❌ Exogenous androgen supplementation:
Incorrect: Athletes may use anabolic steroids to increase muscle mass and height gain. The medication can also have numerous side-effects including aggression, acne, and hypertension. In contrast, this patient’s history and physical exam is not concerning for any of the aforementioned side-effects.
❌ Mutation of RET proto-oncogene:
Incorrect: A mutation in the RET gene can cause multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2A or 2B. MEN2B predisposes patients to developing thyroid cancer, pheochromocytomas, mucosal neuromas, and a marfanoid habitus, which is characterized by tall stature and long limbs. However, this condition would not typically cause macrognathia or visual field defects.
✅ Growth hormone overproduction:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of fatigue and a cough that is productive of blood-tinged sputum. His symptoms began four months ago. Past medical history is notable for emphysema and hypertension. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Physical examination reveals 4/5 strength in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. Ecchymoses and striae are noted on the abdomen. Laboratory testing reveals a fasting blood glucose of 147 mg/dL. Chest X-ray shows a mass in the perihilar region of the left lung. A 24-hour urine sample reveals an elevated cortisol level. A high-dose dexamethasone test is subsequently ordered as part of the patient’s work-up. Which of the following ACTH levels would be expected before and after the high-dose dexamethasone is administered?
questions.solution:
This patient has Cushing syndrome secondary to ectopic ACTH secretion by a lung malignancy.  

The first step in the work-up is to measure free cortisol in a 24-hour urine sample. Alternatively, blood or saliva tests at midnight can help check if there is a normal daily rise and fall of cortisol levels. Another option is the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test. During the test the individual is given a low dose of dexamethasone, an exogenous steroid that suppresses pituitary ACTH production. In healthy individuals, this would cause a decrease in serum cortisol levels.  

If any of the aforementioned tests yield abnormal results, the next step is to determine the exact cause of excess cortisol production. This involves measuring plasma ACTH levels. Low ACTH levels are seen in adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinomas, and exogenous glucocorticoid use. In contrast, high ACTH levels are seen in patients with Cushing disease (ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) and ectopic ACTH production. The patient in this vignette has ectopic ACTH production by a lung malignancy. So his ACTH measurement will be elevated.  

In patients with high ACTH levels, the next step is to give a high-dose injection of dexamethasone. If there is no decline in ACTH levels, it means there is an ectopic site of ACTH production. If levels of ACTH fall after the high-dose dexamethasone test, then Cushing disease is the cause. Since this patient has ectopic ACTH secretion, his levels will remain elevated after administering high-dose dexamethasone.  

Option Analysis

❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Decreased  Decreased :
Incorrect: Patients with hypercortisolism due to exogenous corticosteroid use or adrenal overproduction will present with decreased ACTH levels. Administration of high-dose steroids will prompt additional negative feedback, causing further decreases in ACTH secretion. However, the X-ray findings, in combination with a history of blood-tinged sputum production, suggest that an ACTH-secreting lung malignancy is the most likely cause of his presentation.
❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Decreased  Increased:
Incorrect: Patients with hypercortisolism due to exogenous corticosteroid use or adrenal overproduction will have decreased ACTH levels. High-dose dexamethasone administration would only increase the negative feedback to the pituitary gland, thus further decreasing ACTH production.
❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Increased Decreased :
Incorrect: These findings are seen in patients with an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the high-dose dexamethasone is administered, sufficient negative feedback will be present to decrease pituitary ACTH secretion. However, the X-ray findings and patient’s history suggest that an ACTH-secreting lung malignancy is the most likely cause of his presentation. High-dose dexamethasone cannot suppress ectopic ACTH production. 
✅   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Increased Increased:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Before High-Dose Dexamethasone  After High-Dose Dexamethasone  Normal Decreased :
Incorrect: These findings would be observed in a healthy individual. Administration of the high-dose dexamethasone would result in elevated serum corticosteroid levels. This would cause negative feedback on the pituitary gland and would therefore decrease ACTH production. However, healthy individuals would not present with muscle weakness, ecchymoses, and abdominal striae. All of these are symptoms of hypercortisolism, which is consistent with this patient’s elevated urine cortisol level.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a follow-up visit. At her prior visit several months ago, the patient had persistent hypertension, with a blood pressure measured at 153/89 mmHg. Laboratory testing showed an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Abdominal imaging revealed an adrenal adenoma located in the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. The patient’s blood pressure at this current visit is 156/87 mmHg. This patient most likely has which of the following additional symptoms?

choices.text: Pitting edema of the lower extremities

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with persistent hypertension and an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio. Imaging reveals an adrenal tumor in the zona glomerulosa. In combination, these findings are concerning for an aldosteronoma.

Hyperaldosteronism secondary to an aldosterone-secreting adrenal adenoma is termed Conn syndrome. The most important clinical consequence of hyperaldosteronism is hypertension. The high levels of aldosterone will lead to hypokalemia, hypernatremia, and metabolic alkalosis. Significant hypokalemia may occur in some affected individuals, resulting in muscular aches and weakness, muscle spasms, numbness, and heart palpitations.

Additionally, Conn syndrome does not usually cause edema because of an “aldosterone escape” mechanism. The mechanism occurs since the surge in blood volume secondary to hyperaldosteronism stimulates the atria of the heart to release high levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). The ANP then leads to compensatory diuresis and “escape” from edema and severe hypernatremia.





 

Option Analysis

✅ Muscle weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Episodic palpitations and diaphoresis:
Incorrect: Pheochromocytomas are neoplasms of chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla that overproduce catecholamines (e.g., epinephrine, norepinephrine). Although pheochromocytomas can also cause hypertension, they are associated with paroxysmal episodes of hypertension, diaphoresis, and palpitations. In contrast, this patient has persistent hypertension.
❌ Scattered ecchymoses:
Incorrect: Cushing syndrome, which can arise due to an adrenal tumor in the zona fasciculata (not zona glomerulosa), would result in hypercortisolism. Cushing syndrome can also present with hypertension. Moreover, the excess cortisol would cause weight gain, muscle atrophy, and collagen loss resulting in thin, fragile skin that is easily bruised. However, this patient has a tumor in the zona glomerulosa, which is more concerning for an aldosteronoma.
❌ Pitting edema of the lower extremities:
Incorrect: Hyperaldosteronism does not usually cause edema due to the “aldosterone escape” mechanism. The mechanism occurs since a surge in blood volume secondary to hyperaldosteronism stimulates the atria of the heart to release high levels of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP). The ANP then leads to compensatory diuresis and “escape” from edema and severe hypernatremia.
❌ Bitemporal hemianopsia:
Incorrect: Pituitary tumors can compress the optic chiasm and result in bitemporal hemianopsia. However, this patient has an elevated aldosterone-to-renin ratio and CT imaging showing an adrenal mass. As a result, his symptoms are more likely due to an aldosterone-producing adrenal tumor.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of fatigue, easy bruising, and 7 kg (15 lb) weight gain over the past three months. Past medical history is notable recurrent multiple sclerosis flare-ups. She is currently being treated with oral prednisone. The patient is not taking any other medications. On the physical examination, there is symmetric muscle weakness in the upper and lower extremities. The patient also has wide reddish-purple streaks most prominent on the abdomen. Examination of the patient’s face reveals the following findings:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  
Laboratory testing reveals a fasting serum glucose of 147 mg/dL. Which of the following sets of additional findings would most likely be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has Cushing syndrome secondary to exogenous corticosteroid use. The most common cause of Cushing syndrome is chronic corticosteroid use, often for the treatment of autoimmune/inflammatory conditions.  

Normally, the hypothalamus secretes corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH), which stimulates the pituitary gland to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). ACTH travels to the adrenal glands where it targets cells in the adrenal cortex to induce cortisol production. In particular, ACTH targets the zona fasciculata, the layer of the adrenal cortex responsible for cortisol production. Cortisol production is regulated via negative feedback. This means that high levels of cortisol inhibit hypothalamic and pituitary secretion of CRH and ACTH, respectively.

In this scenario, the oral prednisone that the patient is taking can cause negative feedback on the hypothalamus and the pituitary gland. This leads to a decrease in CRH and ACTH levels, which in turn shuts down cortisol production from the zona fasciculata. Over time, this lack of stimulation can cause the zona fasciculata of both adrenal glands to shrink and become atrophic.   

Option Analysis

❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Elevated  Hyperplasia :
Incorrect: These findings are observed in patients with secondary hypercortisolism. The most common cause of secondary hypercortisolism is an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. However this patient has an autoimmune condition that is being treated with oral steroids. This makes exogenous hypercortisolism a more likely cause of her symptoms.
❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Elevated Atrophy:
Incorrect: This is seen in patients with hypocortisolism secondary to adrenal gland atrophy. The body will increase ACTH levels in an attempt to produce more cortisol. However, hypocortisolism would not present with weight gain, round faces, muscle atrophy, and abdominal striae. Instead, these symptoms are seen in hypercortisolism. 
❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Unchanged Unchanged:
Incorrect: These findings are found in healthy individuals and patients with intermittent steroid use. For example, patients who use corticosteroid inhalers or topical creams on an infrequent basis will have serum cortisol levels within normal range. As a result, ACTH secretion will remain unchanged and the adrenal glands would undergo neither hyperplasia or atrophy.
❌   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland  Decreased Hyperplasia :
Incorrect: This is observed in patients with primary hypercortisolism, which is most often due to adrenal adenomas. In response to corticosteroid overproduction, the body reduces ACTH secretion. However this patient has an autoimmune condition that is being treated with oral steroids. This makes exogenous hypercortisolism the most likely cause of her symptoms.
✅   ACTH Level  Adrenal Gland Decreased Atrophy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
